Yes, Franco's oppressive regime did significantly limit the development of Spanish cinema during his time, as the regime controlled the film industry and heavily censored the content of films. 

Under Franco's dictatorship, filmmakers were required to submit their scripts to the government's censorship board before filming. The government censored anything that was deemed "harmful to the general interests of Spain," including anything that challenged the regime's ideology, authority or morality. This led to a significant amount of artistic censorship and self-censorship in the Spanish film industry, which made it challenging for filmmakers to experiment with new ideas and forms. 

As a result, many Spanish filmmakers during Franco's regime chose to work outside of their country or use allegory and metaphor to express their critique of the regime. Despite these challenges, some Spanish filmmakers were able to produce important works of cinema, such as the surrealist film "Un chien andalou" by Luis Buñuel and "La escopeta nacional" by Luis García Berlanga. 

Overall, Franco's oppressive regime did put a significant damper on the development of Spanish cinema during his time, but some filmmakers were still able to create important works that explored the depth and complexity of the human condition.
